title: R41010
content: The Supreme Court has held in abeyance the question of whether a demonstration of actual innocence would render a defendant's execution unconstitutional. Davis's habeas petition raised these questions, but the courts concluded that his case did not warrant relief. Davis was convicted of murder and other charges related to the shooting of a police officer. The security guard was shot outside a fast food restaurant, leading to the death sentence of the perpetrator, Davis. He petitioned for habeas relief based on constitutional claims and actual innocence, but his requests were rejected by the courts. Davis was convicted of murder and other charges related to the shooting of a police officer. The Georgia Supreme Court affirmed the denial of Davis's petition for a new trial, despite dissent from four members who believed his new evidence was not weighed properly. Davis then sought federal habeas relief, claiming innocence of the murder he was convicted of, but his application was denied by a divided panel for not meeting the requirements for a second habeas petition.
